title: Downton Abbey bosses call for sequel as movie rakes in £110 million
text:
Downton Abbey bosses are looking for the sequel (Picture: Focus)

Downton Abbey bosses are looking ahead to a sequel following the unsurprising success of the first film

The main cast of the hit ITV series returned for the story’s first big-screen outing which focused on a visit from the royal family in 1927, which throws the Crawley family into disarray and sees them come face-to-face with King George V and Queen Mary.

However, it has been claimed that with a current worldwide total of $135.4 million (£110 million), distributor Focus Features have kindly asked the creator and writer of the show, Julian Fellowes, to start work on a follow-up.

The film reportedly cost $20 million (£16 million) so it’s already made nearly seven times its costs; not bad for a period drama that began life on Sunday evenings on ITV.

‘Downton’s popularity as a film has been phenomenal. It took £60million in America alone and has been a roaring success. Julian and the team are over the moon with how it played out. No one expected it would be this big,’ an insider has now claimed.

Speaking to The Sun, they added: ‘The commercial viability of a second film is now a dead cert, so Julian has been told to start putting pen to paper on the follow-up.’

The film saw the likes of Dame Maggie Smith taking another turn as Dowager Countess of Grantham, Michelle Dockery as Lady Mary, Elizabeth McGovern as her mother Cora, Hugh Bonneville as the Earl of Grantham and Laura Carmichael as Lady Edith.

Newcomers included Imelda Staunton as Lady Bagshaw, the cousin of Lady Violet (Dame Maggie Smith) along with Kate Phillips and Simon Jones who play the monarch and Queen who visit the Crawleys in the movie.

Downton Abbey is in cinemas now.
